_prev_prog_3.Description: This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Prima Wawona has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Prima Wawona has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Prima Wawona, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Prima Wawona has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name           | Process Chemical         | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 South System          Anhydrous Ammonia          39,000

P2 East System           Anhydrous Ammonia          12,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 



Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to me

et CalARP and RMP obligations as well



Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices



Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions

1.2.1 Facility Overview



Prima Wawona operates a commercial cold storage for stone fruit and citrus in Cutler, CA. The facility has two ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



P1 (South)



(9) Cold Storage Rooms



(2) Precool Rooms



(2) Conditioning Rooms



(3) Hallways



(1) Loading Dock



(1) Glycol Heat Exchanger



P2 (East)



(10) Bin Rooms



1.2.2 Facility Location



Prima Wawona is located at 12133 Avenue 408 Cutler CA 93615. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.528488, -119.302961. The facility is located approximately 12 miles east of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.



Flood Hazards



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Seismic Susceptibility



Prima Wawona is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Prima Wawona has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.

1.2.4 Process Chemistry



The

refrigeration system employed at Prima Wawona is configured for flooded and pumped overfeed operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receivers



The purpose of each high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration systems. Each high pressure receiver receives high pressure liquid from the condensers or thermosyphon vessel and supplies high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration and reciruclator. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. Each high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulators



The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the suction accumulators. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Recirculator (Pump Drum)



The purpose of the recirculator (pump drum) is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in evaporators throughout the facility. The recirculator receives liquid from the high pressure receiver and supplies, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the vessel. Liquid and vapor returned from the e

vaporators is separated inside the recirculator to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the recirculator contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Pot



The purpose of the oil pot is to provide a safe location to drain oil from the refrigeration system. The oil pot receives liquid ammonia and oil from the recirculator (pump drum) and vent ammonia vapor back to the recirculator. The oil pot is equipped with an oil drain valve which is used to drain oil from the system as needed. Under normal conditions, the oil pot contains low pressure liquid ammonia, low pressure vapor ammonia, and refrigerant oil.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)



The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. The liquid ammonia enters the bottom of the evaporator coil and as the liquid boils into a vapor, it rises through the coil and returns to the flooded accumulator. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Pumped Overfeed)



The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The Rooms 3 and 4 air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the pump drum. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which t

he low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Plate and Frame Heat Exchanger



The purpose of the plate and frame heat exchanger is to remove heat from the glycol solution being pumped through it. The plate and frame heat exchanger receives liquid from a flooded accumulator  where it flows through the channels in the plates and absorbs the heat from the glycol solution on the opposite side of each plate. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the plate and frame heat exchanger and is returned to the flooded accumulator. Under normal conditions, the plate and frame heat exchanger contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Suction Accumulators



The purpose of each suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. Each suction accumulator receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the suction accumulators drains by gravity into the dump traps. Each suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the suction accumulators contain low pressure vapor ammonia.



Dump Traps



The purpose of each dump trap is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration systems back to the high pressure receivers. Each dump trap receives liquid from the s

uction accumulators. Once the liquid level in the dump trap reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the dump trap to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain, by gravity, into the high pressure receivers. Under normal conditions the dump traps can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors



The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the suction accumulators and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. Each compressor has an integral oil separator that receives the high pressure vapor and separates residual oil from the ammonia so that the oil can be returned to the compressor. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers



The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators and compressors to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers or thermosyphon receiver. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. Water is contained in the sump of the condenser, which is then pumped and sprayed over the ammonia coil. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers or thermosyphon receiver. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Thermosyphon Receiver



The purpose of the thermosyp

hon receiver is to provide a supply of liquid ammonia necessary to cool the oil in the compressors. The thermosyphon receiver receives high pressure liquid from the condensers and supplies high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon oil cooler on each screw compressor. Excess liquid in the thermosyphon receiver is piped to the high pressure receiver. High pressure ammonia vapor formed in each oil cooler is returned to the thermosyphon receiver. Under normal conditions, the thermosyphon receiver contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Coolers



The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through it. The oil cooler receives liquid from the thermosyphon receiver. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil cooler and is returned to the thermosyphon receiver. Under normal conditions, the oil cooler contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia. 



1.2.5 Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection System



Each machinery room is equipped with an ammonia detector. The detectors are configured to alert personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm. Audible/visual alarms are available outside the machinery room. If the concentration reaches 75 ppm, each emergency ventilation system will be activated. If the concentration exceeds 90 ppm, the detectors will shut each system down. The detectors installed inside each refrigerated area/room are configured to initiate the same sequence of events. 



Emergency Control Box



Each Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed on the south wall of the machinery room and contains three (3) valves.



P1 (South)



Valve #59: High Side Discharge Valve



Valve #57: Low Side Discharge Valve



Valve #58: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



P2 (East)



Valve #74: High Side Discharge Valve



Valve #72: Low Side Discharge Valve



Valve #73: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



Opening Valves #59 or #74 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Va

lves #57 or #72 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valves #58 or #73 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. 



Relief Valves



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:



Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;



Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;



All P1 (South) relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank; 



All P2 relief valves terminate to the atmosphere, 7.25 ft above the roof.



Diffusion Tank



The P1 (South) refrigeration system is equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tank. The ammonia diffusion tank is 11'-3" dia. x 24' high (17,846 gallon capacity). At a water level of 18'-0", the tank contains 13,383 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.



Screw Compressor Safety Devices



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:



High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cu

tout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.



Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.



High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.



Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices



Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:



High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.



Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switch



The suction accumulators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors..



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)



Each high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)



The entrances to the machinery rooms and the pump doom are equipped with emergency

refrigeration switches that control power to the refrigeration machinery inside the room. The switches can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.



1.2.6 Process Classification



Each ammonia refrigeration system at Prima Wawona consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Prima Wawona are treated as two (2) independent processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Prima Wawona has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Prima Wawona facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year.  It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  



1.4 Five Year Accide

nt History



Prima Wawona has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Prima Wawona's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:



Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220



U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38



Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)



U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)



California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2



USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95



California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)



Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release but do have select personnel who are trained in Hazwoper FRO. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Prima Wawona has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Prima Wawona continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Prima Wawona's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Prima Wawona's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Prima Wawona has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Prima Wawona has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Prima Wawona now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Prima Wawona employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Prima Wawona will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
